lexUnit.name: sit.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to move into a position in which one's weight is supported by one's buttocks rather than one's feet and one's back is upright.

sentence.text: He sat bolt upright and started ranting , ` TESCO 'S BLOODY CAR PARK , DERBY !
I sat bolt upright and stared at him in amazement .
I walked across her line of vision and she sat bolt upright in annoyance .
The person on duty disappeared out the back and I went to sit in the same seat where I had sat the night before .
I was already there and she came and sat by me .
The sergeant , whose name was Troth , came back and sat next to Malm .
But Rosa motioned to him to sit , and sat herself down , opposite him at the table , expectant .
Jane sat upright and sipped gratefully .
He sat upright , leaving the gun on the floorboards .
Then the spark flew back into her eyes and she sat upright again .
The horseman threw a couple of sacks over the backs of his horses and sat under the hedge to eat his elevenses .
He sat beside her , close enough for her to feel the heat from his body .
He seated himself at one end , and Emily sat beside him .
He sat back from the microscope for a moment , then looked again .
Bob sat back in his chair , playing with the pepper-mill , grinding a little pile of pepper into his left palm .
He sat back to let this sink in .

The recreational pleasures that ordinary islanders enjoy have become synonymous with the name Jamaica : dancing to the heavily rhythmic musical beat ; taking a little marijuana ( or `` ganja , '' as it 's known here ) , which many Jamaicans view as a kind of medicinal herb ; or simply sitting back and chatting with friends on a bench or street corner , where the situation is described as `` Irie '' the equivalent of `` Everything 's just fine ! ''
